tokenized_answer: The meeting was mainly about the reasons behind and the measurements against the increasing exclusions from school.
The increase brought more pressure to EOTAS in the aspects of finance, transition, curriculum arrangement and the recruitment of professional staff.
Although much time and finance had been devoted to the PRU, the education quality could still not be assured.
The collaboration between the PRU and the schools required to be strengthened.
Besides, training for special education ought to be included in teachers' colleges to meet EOTAS learners' special needs.
Their psychological health was another concerning problem.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: Welcome to the Children, Young People and Education Committee this morning.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: Item 2, then, is an evidence session for our inquiry on education otherwise than at school, and I'm very pleased to welcome our panel of witnesses this morning: Sharon Davies, head of learning, Torfaen County Borough Council and representing the Association of Directors of Education in Wales; Nick Williams, director of education, Swansea city and county council, and representing the Association of Directors of Education in Wales; and David Hopkins, interim head of education at the Welsh Local Government Association.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: And if I can just start by asking you what you believe the main reasons are for the increase in the number of exclusions from school.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: Obviously, I can speak more about my own local authority in Swansea: the numbers have increased about fourfold over the last five, six years, so what's presenting as difficult behaviour can also sometimes be additional learning needs as well, and the system's struggling a little bit to catch up to have enough capacity to do that, so that is placing pressure on schools and then, in turn, pressure on the EOTAS, including our pupil referral units, because, obviously, we just probably haven't got enough capacity at the moment in the system.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: We're all aware of the funding issues and the challenges of funding that face schools in general.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: So, can this lead to more exclusions, because additional learning needs have been hit in light of these challenges, and then that the side-effects of that creates more exclusions?

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: Can I just ask you about transition arrangements, because I know some of the issues that have arisen in my own constituency is when a pupil is in a PRU and then trying to get back into mainstream education?

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: So, we've recognised that, so that we have our staff working very closely with the schools.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: I'll begin with the WLGA, in general, and ask you, in both your areas, what are the challenges to ensure that EOTAS learners have access to a broad and balanced curriculum, and that there are learning opportunities that are appropriate for them?

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: PRUs: clearly, we know that they are following a set curriculum; they are inspected; they are under the control of the local authorities.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: It's kind of what Nick said about capacity, but it's also ensuring the right staff as well, because sometimes, you may have them, but if they move on, or retire, or whatever, there's not a bus load, if you like, of people with that expertise.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: Because sometimes it takes years to build up on that expertise, and therefore, it's quite niche, and once that person has moved on, it's really difficult to start all over again.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: And should local authorities take a greater role in quality assuring individual tuition?

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: Therefore, it's really difficult then to quality assure, because unless the families invite us in there's very little—.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: If you can't guarantee quality in any shape or form for a young person, it is a concern.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: So, I suppose that comes down to additional funding, because I'd like a dedicated educational psychologist spending their time possibly only with our PRU youngsters and EOTAS provision, but we haven't got the capacity because of the demands on us from the wider system.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: Collaboration, I think, is the answer, between the PRUs and the schools.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: Collaborate and have joint working to ensure that the learners have what they need.

evidence.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
evidence.content: There really isn't the capacity for them to access professional training.

evidence.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
evidence.content: So, is there any way that local authorities can encourage specialist teachers and educational psychologists to actually share expertise with independent providers of EOTAS?

evidence.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
evidence.content: But you're saying, really, take it back to teacher training and start at that point so that every teacher has at least some basic awareness of dealing with education in that setting.

evidence.speaker: Dawn Bowden AM
evidence.content: What's your experience of EOTAS learners' access to mental health support?

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: I was going to say, about the question, I think there's a general deficit in child and adolescent mental health services, for example.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: I suspect—I've not got an evidence base to offer you, but there's a very long-standing problem there.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the funding issues?
tokenized_answer: The committee admitted that the funding issues brought more pressure on schools, especially after the new Act, for they would have to spend more in the light of it.
It was pointed out that the government had not noticed the staff in the PRU, who required training.
The committee was trying to communicate with Estyn and the Welsh Government for a broader range of measures to provide opportunities for schools and local authorities.

evidence.speaker: Lynne Neagle AM
evidence.content: We've got some questions now on funding from Siân Gwenllian.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: In particular now with the new Act coming into force, that's going to place more pressure on the system.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: And sometimes, they have to look at every aspect within the school in terms of their learners, then, and that does place additional pressure on the schools.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: But maybe we need to spend more in light of the new Act?

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams

evidence.content: But just sometimes, the Government doesn't think about the staff in the pupil referral units, because we've gone back to the Government to tell them, 'Right, you've provided money to school staff, but what about staff that need training—perhaps more than staff in the school sector?'

evidence.content: So, it's a little bit of an afterthought.

evidence.content: We're trying to agree with partners, including Estyn and the Welsh Government, a broader range of measures.'

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: That, in a sense, may provide opportunities for schools, and local authorities, to look more constructively at this whole area.

specific_query_list.query: What did David Hopkins think of the new Act?
tokenized_answer: David Hopkins agreed with Sharon Davies that the new Act would exert more pressure on schools.

Meanwhile, he suggested that it would be better for the schools' headmasters and local authorities to look at the new Act more constructively, for it would be beneficial for the post-16 sector.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: I'm not sure whether it's being worse affected, but certainly there's pressure, in particular with the new Act coming in, and that's going to place more pressure on the system.

evidence.speaker: Sian Gwenllian AM
evidence.content: But just the pressures coming in with the new Act et cetera could mean more expulsions.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: That, in a sense, may provide opportunities for schools, and local authorities, to look more constructively at this whole area.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: So, that's one area, but you're right, I think the ALN legislation will put pressures on, not just local authorities and schools, but also on the post-16 sector, because we're talking now about a wider age range—doing up to 25 as well.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: So, we've got a host of issues, I think, there to consider and work our way through.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: The delegation levels are already very high in most authority areas, and we've got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, is devolved to schools.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: So, I don't think that's a direct factor.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: It's difficult to know how headteachers and governing bodies will react.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: That, in a sense, may provide opportunities for schools, and local authorities, to look more constructively at this whole area.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: So, that's one area, but you're right, I think the ALN legislation will put pressures on, not just local authorities and schools, but also on the post-16 sector, because we're talking now about a wider age range—doing up to 25 as well.

specific_query_list.query: What was considered by David Hopkins as the factor that affected exclusions?
tokenized_answer: David Hopkins did not think that the delegation levels were not high enough in most authority areas.
Instead, he thought they had got agreements with the government to make sure that enough money was devolved to school.
The true decisive factor was the narrow measure at the end of Stage 4 that drove the headmasters to exclude students or put them into another school.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: The delegation levels are already very high in most authority areas, and we've got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, is devolved to schools.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: The delegation levels are already very high in most authority areas, and we've got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, is devolved to schools.

evidence.speaker: David Hopkins
evidence.content: I think the factors that really affect exclusions, which is where I think the question came from: you've got the very narrow measure at the end of key stage 4 attainment, which I think has put pressure on some schools, certainly, and headteachers have felt that—sometimes excluded, or otherwise put into another school as a consequence, which is regrettable, but that's what's happened.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the networking within the PRU and the transition arrangements?
tokenized_answer: There had been improvements in the networking within the PRU, for they had national meetings on a regular basis, which could lead to a better sharing of practice.
The PRU was planning to provide teachers with professional training.
On the transition arrangement, the PRU was building a brand new provision in Swansea.
The PRU would support students through a part-time timetable back into school.
Besides, the support would not stop as soon as the students returned to school; the reduction of support would be managed.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: What more can be done, and by whom, to support collaborative working between schools, PRUs and local authorities to ensure that there is a continuum of provision and support for learners?

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: Well, one of the things I think that has improved a lot is the networking within the PRU sector.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: We meet on a regular basis, and that's nationally.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: So, there's definitely a better sharing of practice.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: We put on some very, very good conferences as one form of professional learning.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: And we're talking about professional learning for any teacher or provider, or it's sometimes the more informal training they receive by making visits, joint visits, to provision and also using the expertise that we do have within the sector to work more closely with our schools, and vice versa, particularly around the curriculum.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: Can I just ask you about transition arrangements, because I know some of the issues that have arisen in my own constituency is when a pupil is in a PRU and then trying to get back into mainstream education?

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: We've had a big investment of time, and there will be money and through band B, we're building a brand-new PRU provision in Swansea, which will be open in January 2021.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: There's an integration through a part-time timetable back into school, and we continue to support them during that process.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: But then, when they're back in school, that support doesn't stop—that support continues, and then there's a managed reduction in that support.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: And that's proven very successful.

specific_query_list.query: What was the major challenge of the transition of the excluded students?
tokenized_answer: The students coming to the end of their statutory education were facing the biggest challenge, for it would be far more difficult for them to go back into the mainstream education process when they turned 15 or 16, not to mention the transition into further education, such as colleges.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: But I'll be honest with you, the more challenging your learners are the ones who are coming to the end of their statutory education, your key stage 4.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: It is far, far more difficult when they're 15, 16 to get them back into mainstream.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: So, then you're looking more at how you transit, then, into further education and colleges and so on.

specific_query_list.query: What was the solution to the major challenge for the transition of the excluded students?
tokenized_answer: Sharon Davies recommended the team-around-the-family approach to ensure what was needed for learners to go back into school, as well as what the school could provide.
She pointed out the importance of the whole package of support, which not only surrounded the learners but also their families.

In addition, she gave an example of the PRU in Oxford who built the partnership between the school and the PRU student to demonstrate the responsibility of schools and the significance of school participation.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: It comes back to that team-around-the-family approach, to ensure what is needed for that learner to go back into school, what can the school provide.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: It's looking at the whole package of support, then, that surrounds not just the learner but the family, whether it's transport—it's looking at the whole agenda, then, to ensure that everything is in place for that learner to go back to school, where it's possible.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: A few years ago, I used to be a primary headteacher in England, so we were looking at different models, then, at various conferences, and I believe Oxford, as a local authority—they had a PRU, and they had discussions with their secondary schools, then, whether to get rid of the PRU, as such, and give the money back into schools.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: But they looked at a partnership within the schools, then, to say, 'Okay, you can have the money, but there's got to be terms of reference'—not quite a service level agreement, but the schools worked together as a partnership, then, so that they couldn't keep moving the children around, the learners around.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: It started off really well, but that was a few years ago, so I don't know whether it's continued now.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: But that was a model that, at the time, that local authority looked at to get more money into schools and to get schools, then, to have that responsibility—that they didn't offload the learners elsewhere.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the pros and cons of local authoritative frameworks?
tokenized_answer: One of the advantages was that youngsters' voice could be heard in time if they showed the willingness to go back into school; the framework offered the excluded learners a cooling-off period.
The disadvantage was mainly some individual schools' lack of capacity to organize and offer additional training.
Monitor and evaluation systems of the EOTAS provision were supposed to be set up to ensure the education quality.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: Sometimes, it works really well; sometimes, the learner turns around and says, 'Actually, I preferred it in my old school.'

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: So, there's a cooling-off period as well.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: I think the learner voice is very important there, because—.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: Obviously, we do do that, but we're struggling sometimes for additional provision—very important around safeguarding.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: But, to actually offer some additional training is a challenge.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: To what extent do local authorities know about the level of EOTAS provision that is organised by individual schools, whether in an FE college or otherwise off the school site?

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: We know, as part of that plan that we ask our schools to send in, they have to put down where that provision is.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: And obviously, as part of the visits, as well, to the schools by the challenge advisers, the school should be monitoring that provision and quality assuring that provision.

specific_query_list.query: What did Sharon Davies think of the role that local authorities should take in the quality assurance of individual intuition?
tokenized_answer: Sharon Davies expressed her strong objection to the exclusions caused by tuition or safeguarding.
She pointed out that the difficulty with home tuition was the limited access the local authority could get into the families.
The quality of home tuition was difficult to assure, unless the families invited them there, which was a really rare situation.
All in all, the role of local authorities was restricted in this aspect.

evidence.speaker: Janet Finch-Saunders AM
evidence.content: Individual tuition in terms of we wouldn't want any child, if they're away from a main-school setting, to slip through the net in terms of tuition, or safeguarding even.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: I suppose the difficulty with home tuition is, as a local authority, we're restricted on how much access we get into the home.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: Therefore, it's really difficult then to quality assure, because unless the families invite us in there's very little—.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies
evidence.content: We are restricted in that respect.

specific_query_list.query: Summarize the conclusion of the discussion about the intuition in a private setting.
tokenized_answer: The intuition in a private setting was supposed to follow a restricted timetable, for no matter for what reason the students' need cannot be met at school, the PRU staff ought to provide them with some education.
Besides, the education provided should be different from the education provided by agency staff, who merely offered a few hours' provision or the service offered by local libraries.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: If they're following a restricted timetable or whatever, because maybe they're school anxious and so on, and we're trying to get them into our provision like that, the home-tuition staff work for us.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: So, for whatever reason their needs at the moment can't be met in a school or in approved provision, then the staff who do provide some education, or if it's for medical reasons, they work for us in the local authority.

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
evidence.content: We don't use agency staff, for instance, to go in and provide a few hours of provision, or to go to the local library.

evidence.speaker: Sharon Davies

evidence.speaker: Nick Williams
